title: ABS Modulator - Removal

body.body: Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall, causing injury to the operator or damage to the motorcycle.
Caution - Do not spill brake fluid
To prevent paint damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork. Spilled brake fluid will damage paintwork.
Before the disassembly of any brake lines in the ABS hydraulic circuit, always mark their position so that they can be returned to the same position when assembled.
If the brake lines are incorrectly assembled the performance of the ABS system will be seriously compromised, leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Do not allow the brake hard lines to become bent or kinked during ABS modulator removal.
If the brake lines are bent or kinked the performance of the ABS system will be seriously compromised, leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Release the fixing and remove the rear ABS wheel speed sensor. Collect the shim from between the sensor and rear caliper carrier and discard the fixing.

body.name: Rear ABS wheel speed sensor fixing, chzq_1

body.body: Note the position of the rear brake caliper for installation.
Remove the rear brake caliper and carrier assembly.

body.name: Rear Caliper Carrier and Swinging Arm, L0311

body.body: Make sure no damage is made to the brake pad material when moving the brake pads.
Allowing the brake pads to come into contact with each other or sharp objects may cause the material to crack or break.
Damage to the brake pads may result in reduced braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.

Using a suitable flat metal plate approximately 2 mm thick and 30 to 50 mm wide (for example a gasket scraper) between the brake pads, pump the rear brake pedal slowly until the plate is held by the brake pads. Do not allow the pistons to fall out.
Make sure no damage is made to the brake pad material when moving the brake pads.
Allowing the brake pads to come into contact with each other or sharp objects may cause the material to crack or break.
Damage to the brake pads may result in reduced braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Remove the front caliper mounting fixings and slide the brake caliper off the brake disc.

Using a suitable flat metal plate approximately 2 mm thick and 30 to 50 mm wide (for example a gasket scraper) between the brake pads, pump the rear brake pedal slowly until the plate is held by the brake pads. Do not allow the pistons to fall out.
Before the disassembly of any brake lines in the ABS hydraulic circuit, always mark their position so that they can be returned to the same position when assembled.
If the brake lines are incorrectly assembled the performance of the ABS system will be seriously compromised, leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
To prevent paint damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork.
Close the brake reservoir and wash any spilled brake fluid immediately with warm soapy water.
Spilled brake fluid, if left, will damage painted and plastic surfaces.
Remove the four brake line unions and, taking care not to bend the brake lines, detach the lines from the ABS modulator.
Note the positions of the three grommets on the ABS modulator bracket.
Release the two fixings and shouldered washers for the left hand side of the ABS modulator mounting bracket. Discard the fixings.
Release the fixing and shouldered washer for the right hand side of the ABS modulator mounting bracket. Discard the fixing.
Carefully manoeuvre the ABS modulator and bracket assembly from the motorcycle.
If necessary, release the fixings and remove the mounting bracket. Discard the fixings.
